Material Science.name: Atomic Packing Factor

variables.N: Number of atoms per unit cell

Material Science.description: The atomic packing factor (APF) measures the efficiency of atom packing in a crystal structure, indicating how densely atoms are arranged in different lattice types.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the APF for a body-centered cubic (BCC) lattice with lattice parameter } a = 2.87 \times 10^{-10} \text{ m and atomic radius } R = 1.24 \times 10^{-10} \text{ m.}
example.solution:
\begin{aligned}
\text{In a BCC lattice, } N = 2 \text{ (atoms per unit cell)} \\
\text{Volume of atoms: } V_s &= N \cdot \frac{4}{3} \pi R^3 = 2 \cdot \frac{4}{3} \pi (1.24 \times 10^{-10})^3 \\
&= 2 \cdot \frac{4}{3} \pi (1.9066 \times 10^{-30}) \approx 8.013 \times 10^{-30} \text{ m}^3 \\
\text{Volume of unit cell: } V_c &= a^3 = (2.87 \times 10^{-10})^3 \approx 2.363 \times 10^{-29} \text{ m}^3 \\
APF &= \frac{V_s}{V_c} = \frac{8.013 \times 10^{-30}}{2.363 \times 10^{-29}} \approx 0.339 \text{ or } 33.9\% \\
\text{Thus, the APF is approximately } 0.339 \ \checkmark
\end{aligned}

Material Science.name: Number of Vacancies

variables.Q_v: Activation energy required to form a vacancy

Material Science.description: This formula determines the equilibrium concentration of point defects (vacancies) in a crystal at a given temperature, crucial for understanding material properties like diffusion and conductivity.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the number of vacancies in a metal with } N = 10^{28} \text{ sites/m}^3, Q_v = 1.2 \text{ eV, at } T = 1000 \text{ K, given } k = 8.617 \times 10^{-5} \text{ eV/K.}
example.solution:
\begin{aligned}
\text{Given: } N = 10^{28}, \ Q_v = 1.2 \text{ eV}, \ k = 8.617 \times 10^{-5} \text{ eV/K}, \ T = 1000 \text{ K} \\
\text{Calculate exponent: } \frac{Q_v}{k T} &= \frac{1.2}{8.617 \times 10^{-5} \cdot 1000} = \frac{1.2}{0.08617} \approx 13.928 \\
\exp \left( -\frac{Q_v}{k T} \right) &= \exp(-13.928) \approx 1.177 \times 10^{-6} \\
N_v &= N \exp \left( -\frac{Q_v}{k T} \right) = 10^{28} \cdot 1.177 \times 10^{-6} \\
&= 1.177 \times 10^{22} \text{ vacancies/m}^3 \\
\text{Thus, } N_v \approx 1.177 \times 10^{22} \text{ vacancies/m}^3 \ \checkmark
\end{aligned}

Material Science.name: Attractive Force (Coulomb's Law for Ions)
Material Science.description: This formula computes the electrostatic attractive force between oppositely charged ions in ionic bonds, fundamental for understanding ionic crystal stability.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the attractive force between } \text{Na}^+ \text{ and } \text{Cl}^- \text{ ions separated by } r = 2.8 \times 10^{-10} \text{ m, given } q_1 = +1.602 \times 10^{-19} \text{ C}, q_2 = -1.602 \times 10^{-19} \text{ C}, \epsilon_0 = 8.854 \times 10^{-12} \text{ C}^2 / (\text{N} \cdot \text{m}^2).
example.solution:
\begin{aligned}
q_1 = +1.602 \times 10^{-19} \text{ C}, \ q_2 = -1.602 \times 10^{-19} \text{ C} \\
\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_0} = \frac{1}{4 \pi \cdot 8.854 \times 10^{-12}} \approx 8.987 \times 10^9 \text{ N} \cdot \text{m}^2/\text{C}^2 \\
\frac{q_1 q_2}{r^2} &= \frac{(1.602 \times 10^{-19}) \cdot (-1.602 \times 10^{-19})}{(2.8 \times 10^{-10})^2} \\
&= \frac{-2.566 \times 10^{-38}}{7.84 \times 10^{-20}} \approx -3.273 \times 10^{-19} \text{ C}^2/\text{m}^2 \\
F_A &= 8.987 \times 10^9 \cdot (-3.273 \times 10^{-19}) \approx -2.94 \times 10^{-9} \text{ N} \\
\text{Thus, the attractive force is } 2.94 \times 10^{-9} \text{ N (attractive).} \ \checkmark
\end{aligned}

Material Science.name: Repulsive Force
Material Science.description: This formula models the short-range repulsive force due to overlapping electron clouds in atomic bonding, balancing attraction in potential energy curves.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the repulsive force for } b = 10^{-70} \text{ N} \cdot \text{m}^{10}, n = 9, \text{ and } r = 2.5 \times 10^{-10} \text{ m.}

Material Science.name: Net Bonding Energy
Material Science.description: This formula finds the total potential energy between atoms as a function of distance, identifying equilibrium spacing and bond strength.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the net bonding energy for } A = 1.436 \times 10^{-19} \text{ J} \cdot \text{m}, B = 7.32 \times 10^{-78} \text{ J} \cdot \text{m}^9, n = 9, \text{ at } r = 2.8 \times 10^{-10} \text{ m.}
example.solution:
\begin{aligned}
E_{\text{net}} &= -\frac{A}{r} + \frac{B}{r^n} \\
\text{Attractive term: } -\frac{A}{r} &= -\frac{1.436 \times 10^{-19}}{2.8 \times 10^{-10}} \approx -5.129 \times 10^{-10} \text{ J} \\
\text{Repulsive term: } \frac{B}{r^n} &= \frac{7.32 \times 10^{-78}}{(2.8 \times 10^{-10})^9} \\
(2.8 \times 10^{-10})^9 &= (2.8)^9 \times 10^{-90} \approx 1.345 \times 10^{-87} \\
\frac{B}{r^n} &= \frac{7.32 \times 10^{-78}}{1.345 \times 10^{-87}} \approx 5.442 \times 10^{-10} \text{ J} \\
E_{\text{net}} &= -5.129 \times 10^{-10} + 5.442 \times 10^{-10} \approx 3.13 \times 10^{-11} \text{ J} \\
\text{Thus, } E_{\text{net}} \approx 3.13 \times 10^{-11} \text{ J} \ \checkmark
\end{aligned}

Material Science.name: Density of Metal

variables.n: Number of atoms per unit cell

Material Science.description: This formula calculates the theoretical density of metallic crystals from crystal structure parameters.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the density of copper (FCC, } n = 4, M = 63.55 \text{ g/mol, } a = 3.615 \times 10^{-10} \text{ m, } N_A = 6.022 \times 10^{23} \text{ mol}^{-1}).
example.solution:
\begin{aligned}
V_c &= a^3 = (3.615 \times 10^{-10})^3 \approx 4.723 \times 10^{-29} \text{ m}^3 \\
\rho &= \frac{n M}{V_c N_A} = \frac{4 \cdot 63.55}{4.723 \times 10^{-29} \cdot 6.022 \times 10^{23}} \\
&= \frac{254.2}{2.845 \times 10^{-5}} \approx 8.936 \times 10^6 \text{ g/m}^3 \\
&= 8.936 \text{ g/cm}^3 \\
\text{Thus, the density is approximately } 8.94 \text{ g/cm}^3 \ \checkmark
\end{aligned}

Material Science.name: Density of Ceramic

variables.n: Number of formula units per unit cell
variables.\\sum A_C: Sum of atomic masses of cations
variables.\\sum A_A: Sum of atomic masses of anions

Material Science.description: This formula computes the density of ionic ceramics like oxides or halides from their unit cell composition.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the density of NaCl (FCC, } n = 4, A_{\text{Na}} = 22.99 \text{ g/mol, } A_{\text{Cl}} = 35.45 \text{ g/mol, } a = 5.64 \times 10^{-10} \text{ m, } N_A = 6.022 \times 10^{23} \text{ mol}^{-1}).
example.solution:
\begin{aligned}
\sum A_C + \sum A_A &= 22.99 + 35.45 = 58.44 \text{ g/mol} \\
V_c &= a^3 = (5.64 \times 10^{-10})^3 \approx 1.794 \times 10^{-28} \text{ m}^3 \\
\rho &= \frac{n (\sum A_C + \sum A_A)}{V_c N_A} = \frac{4 \cdot 58.44}{1.794 \times 10^{-28} \cdot 6.022 \times 10^{23}} \\
&= \frac{233.76}{1.080 \times 10^{-4}} \approx 2.164 \times 10^6 \text{ g/m}^3 \\
&= 2.164 \text{ g/cm}^3 \\
\text{Thus, the density is approximately } 2.16 \text{ g/cm}^3 \ \checkmark
\end{aligned}

Material Science.name: Degree of Polymerization
Material Science.description: The degree of polymerization indicates the average number of repeat units in polymer chains, relating to molecular weight and properties like viscosity.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the degree of polymerization for a polymer with } \bar{M}_n = 100,000 \text{ g/mol and } \bar{m} = 104 \text{ g/mol (repeat unit).}

Material Science.name: Number-Average Molar Mass

variables.x_i: Mole fraction of chains with molar mass } M_i
variables.M_i: Molar mass of chain species } i

Material Science.description: This formula calculates the average molecular weight based on the number of molecules, important for polymer characterization.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } \bar{M}_n \text{ for a polymer with } x_1 = 0.4, M_1 = 50,000 \text{ g/mol, } x_2 = 0.6, M_2 = 80,000 \text{ g/mol.}

Material Science.name: Weight-Average Molar Mass

variables.w_i: Weight fraction of chains with molar mass } M_i
variables.M_i: Molar mass of chain species } i

Material Science.description: This formula determines the average molecular weight weighted by mass, affecting mechanical properties like strength.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } \bar{M}_w \text{ for a polymer with } w_1 = 0.3, M_1 = 50,000 \text{ g/mol, } w_2 = 0.7, M_2 = 80,000 \text{ g/mol.}

Material Science.name: Number of Repeat Units per Unit Cell

variables.n: Number of repeat units per unit cell

Material Science.description: This formula calculates how many polymer repeat units fit in a crystalline unit cell.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } n \text{ for a polymer with } \rho = 1.2 \text{ g/cm}^3, V_c = 1.0 \times 10^{-22} \text{ cm}^3, A = 104 \text{ g/mol, } N_A = 6.022 \times 10^{23} \text{ mol}^{-1}.

Material Science.name: Percentage Crystallinity
Material Science.description: This formula quantifies the crystalline fraction in semicrystalline polymers, influencing properties like opacity and strength.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the percentage crystallinity for a polymer with } \rho_c = 1.5 \text{ g/cm}^3, \rho_s = 1.3 \text{ g/cm}^3, \rho_a = 1.1 \text{ g/cm}^3.
example.solution:
\begin{aligned}
\% \text{ Crystallinity} &= \frac{\rho_c (\rho_s - \rho_a)}{\rho_s (\rho_c - \rho_a)} \times 100 \\
&= \frac{1.5 (1.3 - 1.1)}{1.3 (1.5 - 1.1)} \times 100 \\
&= \frac{1.5 \cdot 0.2}{1.3 \cdot 0.4} \times 100 = \frac{0.3}{0.52} \times 100 \\
&\approx 57.69 \% \\
\text{Thus, the crystallinity is approximately } 57.7\% \ \checkmark
\end{aligned}

Material Science.name: Average Bearing Stress
Material Science.description: This formula assesses the compressive stress between contacting surfaces, such as in joints or supports.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the bearing stress for } F_b = 5000 \text{ N, } A = 0.02 \text{ m}^2.

Material Science.name: Average Normal Strain
Material Science.description: This formula measures deformation per unit length in materials under load.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the average normal strain for a bar with } L = 1.5 \text{ m, } \Delta L = 0.003 \text{ m.}

Material Science.name: Thermal Strain
Material Science.description: This formula predicts dimensional changes due to temperature variations in materials.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the thermal strain for a material with } \alpha = 12 \times 10^{-6} \text{ /K, } \Delta T = 50 \text{ K.}

Material Science.name: Hooke's Law (Uniaxial)
Material Science.description: Hooke's Law relates stress and strain in the elastic region of materials, foundational for linear elastic behavior.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the stress for a material with } E = 200 \text{ GPa, } \epsilon = 0.001.

Material Science.name: Shear Modulus Relation
Material Science.description: This formula connects shear stiffness to tensile stiffness and lateral contraction in isotropic materials.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the shear modulus for a material with } E = 70 \text{ GPa, } \nu = 0.3.

Material Science.name: Allowable Stress
Material Science.description: This formula ensures that materials operate below failure limits with a safety margin in design.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the allowable stress for } \sigma_{\text{failure}} = 400 \text{ MPa, } FS = 2.

Material Science.name: Factor of Safety
Material Science.description: This formula evaluates how much stronger a material is compared to the loads it experiences.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the factor of safety for } \sigma_{\text{failure}} = 500 \text{ MPa, } \sigma_{\text{actual}} = 125 \text{ MPa.}

Material Science.name: Axial Deformation
Material Science.description: This formula calculates the total elastic deformation in axially loaded bars, applicable to varying sections.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the deformation of a steel bar with } F = 10,000 \text{ N, } L = 2 \text{ m, } A = 0.0005 \text{ m}^2, E = 200 \text{ GPa.}
